PURPOSE FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN RESUBMISSION / UPDATE



Stolthaven Houston Inc. is updating the facility's Risk Management Plan ("RMP") in June of 2016 to add an operating scenario for a regulated flammable substance to be newly handled by Direct Transfers at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, and also to revise various RMP data elements that have changed since the previous plan update submitted in October of 2014.  The specific changes associated with this RMP update include:



- Adding Direct Transfers between Marine Vessels and Rail Tank Cars of two mixtures that contain n-Pentane, and



- Various RMP data element updates based on revisions to Stolthaven Houston's Emergency Action Plan ("EAP") and our Standard Operating Procedures ("SOP") found in the terminal's Local Training Manual ("LTM"). 





? 68.155(a):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



At Stolthaven Houston Inc. we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes related to bulk chemical storage and distribution in a safe and responsible manner.  The facility uses a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs to protect the environment and to ensure the safety of our employees, our industrial neighbors, and the citizens of the surrounding communities.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Stolthaven Houston Inc. has designed and implemented, including:



- A description of our facility and the substances regulated by Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 ("40 CFR 68") that are currently handled on-site in stationary sources above their corresponding threshold quantities



- An overview of our accidental release prevention programs



- A five-year history of significant accidental releases from processes covered by the Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") RMP regulations



- An overview of our emergency response programs



- An overview of planne

d and actual improvements implemented at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets, and



- Detailed information about our Risk Management Program





? 68.155(b):  STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



Stolthaven Houston Inc. owns and operates an existing bulk liquids storage and distribution terminal located on the north side of the Houston Ship Channel near Channelview in eastern Harris County, Texas.  The facility currently consists of 188 large above-ground storage tanks, five truck loading/unloading racks (Truck Racks T-3, T-4, T-5, T-6 and T-8), four rail car loading/unloading racks (Rail Racks R-1, R-2, R-3 and R-5), one barge dock (Barge Dock-C), and a finger pier jetty equipped with two separate marine vessel berths (Ship Dock 2/3).  A rail car cleaning station is located within the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, and a biological waste water treatment plant and various air pollution control devices are also operated on-site to reduce the impact of the Stolthaven Houston Terminal on the environment.



Bulk liquid products are received into the Stolthaven Houston Terminal by various modes of transportation cargo containers that can include tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, rail tank cars, barges, and marine parcel tankers.  The received liquid products are stored on-site according to customer-specified requirements, and are subsequently transferred off-site through one or more of the above-referenced transportation modes.  Stolthaven Houston Inc. also performs direct product transfers between marine vessels and rail tank cars with no intermediate storage in the facility's above-ground storage tanks.  Similarly, land-based intermodal (IMO) transfers directly between tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, and rail tank cars are also performed routinely at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Note that Stolthave

n Houston Inc. does not perform any chemical processing or chemical manufacturing operations on-site, and the company does not own nor ultimately control the disposition of the various bulk liquid products that are stored or otherwise handled at the facility.



The following chemicals handled at Stolthaven Houston Inc. have been identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:



Regulated Toxic Substances Currently in Storage:



Toluene Diisocyanate ("TDI"), Mixed Isomers:  Chemical Abstracts Service ("CAS") Number 26471-62-5

Vinyl Acetate Monomer ("VAM"):  CAS Number 108-05-4



Regulated Flammable Substance Currently Handled via Intermodal Transfer (Rail Car to ISO Container):



Isopentane:  CAS Number 78-78-4



Regulated Flammable Substance Currently Handled via Direct Transfer (Marine Vessels to/from Rail Cars):



n-Pentane (CAS Number 109-66-0, Present in Mixtures Containing up to 16.13-percent n-Pentane)



TDI and VAM currently represent the only two RMP regulated substances at Stolthaven Houston Inc. that are present on-site above their corresponding threshold quantities at all times.  Isopentane is periodically transloaded directly from rail tank cars into ISO tank containers with no intermediate on-site storage other than that associated with rail cars staged on the terminal's storage tracks prior to performing the transfer.  As a result, Isopentane is not always present at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Similarly, Stolthaven Houston Inc. now proposes to perform direct transfers between marine vessels and rail cars of two mixtures that may contain up to 16.13-percent n-Pentane.  Like the Isopentane intermodal transfers, the n-Pentane mixtures will be handled on-site only during the actual direct transfer operations, and while rail cars are held on Stolthaven Houston's storage tracks either prior to, or immediately after, performing the transfers.  The majori

ty of the time the Stolthaven Houston Terminal will not have n-Pentane on-site above the 10,000-pound threshold quantity.  



Our training and accidental release prevention programs in combination with our Standard Operating Procedures ("SOP") and contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the potential hazards posed to our employees, the public, and the environment through the storage and/or transfer of the above-referenced RMP regulated chemicals.



TOLUENE DIISOCYANATE STORAGE AND TRANSFERS



Stolthaven Houston Inc. currently stores TDI in one 30,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tank (Low-Pressure Storage Tank D30-10) and in two 15,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tanks (Low-Pressure Storage Tanks D15-19 and D15-22).  Tank D30-10 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 10,600,000-pounds (1,042,000-gallons).  Tank D15-19 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 5,122,000-pounds (503,600-gallons).  Tank D15-22 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 5,131,000-pounds (504,500-gallons).  Periodic direct transfers of TDI from marine vessels into rail tank cars is also performed at Stolthaven Houston Inc. with no intermediate product storage.  Note that Stolthaven Houston Inc. has over 20-years of experience in the storage and handling of TDI. 



As part of the most recent changes associated with additional TDI storage in Low-Pressure Storage Tank D15-19, significant modifications were performed such that TDI is handled safely and efficiently in this tank, including installing a liner on the storage tank's floor and shell, installing a line constructed of 316L stainless steel from the storage tank to the existing marine dock line in D-Manifold that is used exclusively for TDI marine-based transfers, replacing all existing gate valves on the Tank D15-19 system with ball valves for ease of operation, installing a stainless-steel pump for TDI

at Storage Tank D15-19, installing hot water external heating panels, a water tank, and associated heating panel supply/return lines for Storage Tank D15-19 while in TDI service, insulating Tank D15-19, installing internal eductors at the tank's recirculation line to improve product mixing, installing electric tracing and insulation on the tank's lateral line to D-Manifold, installing a dehydrator on the tank's vacuum breaker to help prevent moisture from entering the vapor space should there be a loss of plant nitrogen, and installing a carbon adsorption canister on the Storage Tank D15-19 vapor line prior to the TDI vapors entering the terminal's common Tank Farm Vent Flare vapor header.  



ISOPENTANE INTERMODAL TRANSFERS



Isopentane is periodically transloaded directly between rail tank cars spotted at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's Rail Rack R-2 into ISO tank containers located at Truck Rack T-6 with no intermediate product storage in any of the terminal's chemical storage tanks.  Vapors generated during these intermittent Isopentane transfer operations are directed to the terminal's Tank Farm Vent Flare for pollution control.  



VINYL ACETATE MONOMER STORAGE AND TRANSFERS



Storage Tank P50-5 is an existing internal floating roof ("IFR") tank at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal with a maximum working capacity of approximately 50,142-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 16,400,000-pounds.  Tank P50-5, which represents the facility's worst-case release scenario, was placed into VAM service for the first time on February 25, 2010.  VAM is received into this tank via barge delivery using a dedicated marine dock line.  Product is stored and then shipped outbound according to customer requirements via marine parcel tankers and occasionally barges that load at Stolthaven Houston's existing Ship Dock 2/3.  VAM may also be transferred periodically directly from barges into rail tank cars with no intermediate product sto

rage, and VAM slops can also be received into the terminal from marine vessels berthed at Stolthaven Houston.  



As a result of the 2010 VAM storage project for Tank P50-5, piping modifications were completed in various facility manifolds and at Tank P50-5 to eliminate the use of hoses in VAM service to the greatest extent possible within the terminal.  A VAM filter-pot was also installed adjacent to the storage tank.  Stolthaven Houston's permanent, stationary fire-water protection systems in the immediate area of Tank P50-5 were also upgraded to provide additional cooling water if-needed in the event of an emergency incident involving any of the the facility's flammable or combustible liquid storage tanks in close proximity.  Existing portable water delivery systems also remain available should they be needed in the event of an emergency.



N-PENTANE MIXTURE DIRECT TRANSFERS



In the summer of 2016 Stolthaven Houston proposes to commence direct transfers between marine vessels and rail tank cars of two unique mixtures that contain n-Pentane.  The first mixture is a blend of various Hexane isomers (commonly referred to as "Isohexanes") that can contain up to 10-percent n-Pentane by volume; this stream will be transferred from rail cars spotted at Stolthaven Houston's Rail Rack R-3 directly into a marine vessel berthed at Stolthaven Houston's Ship Dock 2/3 using either the R3-A1-D3-42 Direct Transfer Line or the R3-A1-D3-41 Direct Transfer Line.  Vapors generated at the marine vessel during direct transfer operations will be controlled using the facility's Marine Loading Flare.  Prior to conducting the direct transfer operation, the pipeline and all transfer hoses must be pre-conditioned with product in order to reduce the risk of contamination during transfer.  Additionally, the transfer line, all transfer hoses, and the ship's cargo tank will be cleaned, inspected, and purged using plant nitrogen to below 500-parts per million ("ppm") oxygen content prior to c

ommencing the product movement.  Rail Rack R-3 at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal is an 8-spot system; as such, up to 8-rail cars can be connected to the direct transfer line simultaneously.



The second mixture (Manufacturer's Trade Name "Kogasol 56") is a C5-C6 paraffin and alkane blend rich in n-Hexane that can contain up to 16.13-percent n-Pentane by volume; this stream will be transferred from a marine vessel berthed at Stolthaven Houston's Ship Dock 2/3 into a maximum of 8-rail cars spotted at Stolthaven Houston's Rail Rack R-3 using either the R3-A1-D3-42 Direct Transfer Line or the R3-A1-D3-41 Direct Transfer Line.  Vapors generated at the rail rack during direct transfer operations will be controlled using the facility's McGill Truck and Rail Car Loading Flare.  Similar to the Isohexane stream, the transfer pipeline and hoses must be pre-conditioned using material from an advance rail car containing n-Pentane; liquid is pushed into the transfer hoses and lines, and is ultimately transferred into a vacuum truck in order to reduce the risk of product contamination during the actual transfer operation from ship to rail cars.  The transfer line, all transfer hoses, and the rail cars will be clean, inspected, and purged using plant nitrogen to below 500-ppm oxygen content prior to commencing the product movement.



Employee training related to the newly covered n-Pentane direct transfer processes was completed for Stolthaven Houston Marine Dock and Rail Rack R-1/R-3 Operations Personnel on June 21, 2016 and June 23, 2016.  In an abundance of caution, for the purpose of worst-case release scenario modeling, full rail car volumes assuming 100-percent n-Pentane were applied.  In reality, a maximum of approximately 16-percent n-Pentane is present in these direct transfer mixtures.  



   

? 68.155(c):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of haza

rdous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:



- Process Safety Information ("PSI")



- Process Hazard Analysis ("PHA")



- ISO 9001:2008 Certified Quality Management System ("QMS")



- Employee Training / LTM



- Mechanical Integrity Program



- Spill Containment



- Management of Change ("MOC")



- Pre-Startup Safety Review ("PSSR")



- Vapor Control Systems



- Compliance Audits



- Formal Incident Investigation



- Employee Participation Program



- Hot Work / Safe Work Permits



- Departmental / Safety Meetings



- Emergency Response Team ("ERT")



- Emergency / Incident Response Contractors



The above-referenced elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we conduct business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls in place to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.





? 68.155(d):  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the preceding five years there has been one accidental release from a RMP covered process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal which resulted in significant property damage on-site.  On the evening of August 23, 2013 nitrogen pressure was being used to unload a rail car containing TDI into one of Stolthaven Houston's on-site TDI storage tanks.  As the rail car was being unloaded, the rail switching crew on-duty coupled the terminal's locomotive to a string of rail cars, including the working TDI rail car, and began to pull the cars away from the rail rack.  As the rail car being emptied of TDI was moved from the unloading spot, the TDI cargo hose released from the top of rail car, and the 1-inch valve connected to the plant nitrogen hose was sheared off of the rail car.  Nitrogen pressure in the rail car caused approximately 4,500-gallons of TDI to be released

from the sheared 1-inch valve opening on the top of the rail car into the Rail Rack R-2 concrete containment area, with a small amount of liquid TDI released onto an in-plant concrete road adjacent to the Rail Rack R-2 in the center of the facility.  There was no off-site release of TDI liquid.  A Stolthaven Houston operator on duty at the rail rack immediately closed the rail rack TDI product line valve leading to the storage tank being filled, and the TDI liquid release from the rail car stopped once the residual nitrogen pressure in the car reached atmospheric pressure.  A third-party environmental response contractor was contacted within an hour of this release to assist with the necessary clean-up efforts, which were completed on the late afternoon of August 27, 2013.



As a result of this incident, the following corrective actions were implemented by Stolthaven Houston Inc. after review by the terminal's Management Steering Committee:  (1) the TDI incident was discussed in detail at a mandatory meeting conducted at Rail Rack R-2 for all facility Operations, Waste Water, and Maintenance Department personnel, (2) Standard Operating Procedures related to rail car switching were formally updated on September 20, 2013, and (3) operator training related to the revised rail car switching and blue flag procedures was conducted during Operations Departmental meetings held according to shift in September of 2013.  



Note that this incident did not result in any on-site deaths or injuries.  Similarly, there have been no accidental releases from any RMP covered processes in the past five years which resulted in known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



All incidents at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal are formally investigated as part of our facility's ISO QMS to identify and correct the root cause(s) of the events, and to implement appropriate corrective actions for continuous process improvement.

? 68.155(e):  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets during potential emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our action plan with the community emergency response plan and the North Channel Local Emergency Planning Committee ("LEPC").  Stolthaven Houston Inc. is also an active member of Channel Industries Mutual Aid ("CIMA").



An Emergency Action Plan ("EAP") is maintained which provides guidelines for responding to various emergencies such as fires, hazardous material spills, personnel injuries, severe weather events, and property damage that may occur at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  





? 68.155(f):  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The following is a list of both completed and planned initiatives at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal to assist in preventing and/or responding to accidental chemical releases, and to help effectively manage the hazards present at the facility:



- In 2014 a new role, Emergency Response Coordinator, was created and filled to the streamline the terminal's efforts in the event of a significant incident at the facility



- As they are emptied and cleaned, toxic and/or flammable product storage tanks at the facility are being equipped with ball valves to replace existing gate valves as part of ongoing safety enhancement and automation efforts



- A complete review, hydraulic study, and engineering analysis of Stolthaven Houston's fire water delivery systems is underway



- Continuous improvement through the facility's ISO 9001:2008 Certified QMS



- Employee Suggestion / Experience Feedback Program



- Safety Committee



- Regular safety meetings with Stolthaven Houston Operations Department employ

ees and contract personnel working in the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, and



- Relocating the facility's Fire House away from plant operating areas that could potentially be affected in the event of an emergency at the facility 



Additional capital budget projects under consideration for future improvements to safety and emergency response at Stolthaven Houston Inc. include the purchase of additional fire fighting foam, purchasing additional fire-fighting equipment and PPE for the company's emergency response team personnel, additional surveillance cameras to be installed around the terminal's east expansion property, and adding concrete paving to five existing tank farms (A, B, F, S, and Q)that currently have earthen floors to improve both secondary containment capability and surface working conditions for employees.
